review:
Absolutely brilliant game, based heavily on the much more modern "Ready or Not" title, this tactical SWAT game is a fantastic alternative to those whose setups cannot run the much-more demanding Ready or Not title. Fantastic gameplay that centers around the use of your Number-Keys to direct orders to your SWAT Teams to achieve their objectives, this is one of only a very few number of games that genuinely gives me jump-scares, when an enemy appears from around a corner and seemingly one-shots you down, every decision you make is vital and will require very careful planning and thorough use of all your Utility (flashbangs, cs gas, mirrors, lock-picks, non-lethal bullets etc), it will also require a restart here or there as each mission is very difficult in it's own unique ways. Fantastic blast-to-the-past from this nostalgia-inducing title from the brilliance of those at Sierra Studios. 
COMPATIBILITY: BE PREPARED to do some work in the files of your desktop to get this thing to run on more modern OS' such as WIndows 10 and Windows 11. The game WILL run seamlessly on these OS' but you will have to follow Steam' Guides to get this game even starting-up and running in 60fps+ however, the guide I used from Steam was perfect in getting the game to run perfectly! Enjoy!

review:
A great FPS (first person shooter) for those who like tactical situations and the thought of being able to play the hero! A large range of scenarios to chose from allows you to play the role of a SWAT team leader. 
Respond to different emergencies and choose the right gear for the job. Go loud or go in quiet. Rescue hostages and decide how to handle situations. Aim to subdue and arrest or go for the kill. Every job is generated different each time you try which keeps replay-ability high. A great classic that still holds its own even today.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143767815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3979, 'last_played': 1627457138}
review:
[h1]Corrupted gang of police motorcyclists breaks Geneva convention and ruins my score[/h1]

But seriously though, this is the [b]best tactical shooter in the history of men[/b], at least among the CQB ones! Yes, even better than the incredible SWAT 4. Don't be scared of it's clunky UI and outdated graphics, because this is certainly the game which deserves to be finished. The AI of your teammates alone is some sort of black magic! Friendly bots scan every corner, shoot very accurately and proceed with disciplined caution - they are indeed useful, however, not overpowered. Swat bots even mark every breached room with a lightstick and correct your reports to command center on the fly. That is the reason why SWAT 3 is actually better than the 4th one, which can be pretty common opinion among some die hard fans. Yes, as a gothic operator i absolutely miss enviromental storytelling in SWAT 4, it's grim New York locations inspired by the movie "Seven", unique personalities of the team members, user-friendly UI, more gameplay options, etc., but the 3rd installment excels exactly in what the 4th one could have done better. 
Here's another example, for unknown reason Irrational games removed highly useful feature from SWAT 3 - 2 phases of assault. When you press a dedicated button your AI squad can instaintly switch from [b]Stealth mode[/b] to [b]Dynamic mode[/b]. A killer feature (no pun intended), because once you've changed the siege style you and your team will move quicker, list of avaliable commands will change to suit aggresive tactics and, most importaintly, your partners-in-law will shoot suspects on sight, but the AI is so remarkable that they won't just insta kill everyone even then, they use force only when there is no other option. 

You can split your team of 4 members to red or blue couple. In-depth in-game menu with detailed list of contextual commands is what makes the experience constantly fresh. Sadly, this feature is much better utilized in SWAT 4. You will simply need to get used to multiple order buttons here and a clunky UI. Confusing as hell at first.

Enemies are dangerous too. Eventhough they are less dynamic and won't roam from room to room like in SWAT 4 they are at times even more focused and won't hesitate to pick the best defense option against you - a.k.a hostage. 

[quote]Of course, this game is too old, but not a tad obsolete. It uses 16-bit color palette plus there can be other unforseen issues. Take a note about these fixing methods:
[list][*]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=937035975
[*]https://steamcommunity.com/app/560370/discussions/0/3062995463263825909/
[*]https://steamcommunity.com/app/560370/discussions/0/3119273879022263103/[/list][/quote]

Also not everyone was fond of pacifistic rating system in SWAT 4 which forced you to use pepperball gun/taser/less than lethal shotgun against suspects to achieve the best score possible. That is not an issue with this game. Though i still liked that extra layer of gameplay depth in SWAT 4, what i appreciate about the 3rd one is it's straight forwardness when it comes to goals. You don't even need to clear the entire location if some additional civilians were left, because mission briefing is always based on some sort of goverment reconnaissance without extra civs - you know, the ones who could have been ended up in this place by accident. SWAT 3 won't punish you severely for not being a scout boy or complete pacifist just because you forgot to bring in your pepperball gun, [strike]while sniffing evidence cocaine, you - idiot sandwitch of a cop![/strike] But you can play as different officers and get a medal as an award, so there is still something to master, not to mention sheer game design lack of bottom: NPCs will appear in random places each time like in SWAT 4.

Aside from some tricky workarounds to make the damn thing boot up, SWAT 3 is out of major flaws, only some minor ones. Firstly, i can't understand why my boys are wearing these weird motorcycle helmets. Never seen any kind of tactical protection like this. The game contains extra skins by default or you can apply various mods for them, but they are not presented in the main campagin. Morever, you can complain about limited amounts of content: not many weapons, only a few customization options. Also worth mentioning that, unfortunately, the community lacks Discord server, so it's hard finding some partners for coop (you can message me though).

What's also cool about the game is the ability to change reaction times for AI via main menu. GOTY edition provides a few neat mods, like proper SWAT uniforms and even a 10 man campagin. Frankly, the 2nd team of 5 psychopaths with fogged up motorcycle helmets will be controlled by AI, however it's pretty useful to send them on another infiltration point. You can even hear their reports to command center on your radio frequency.

Overall SWAT 3 is undeservedly forgotten masterpiece. This game do what it aims for with laser focus. The AI, the complex level design, the amount of tactical options, the variety, the [u]fair[/u] challenge, the methodical gameplay - you name it. SWAT 3 to tactical shooters is what Thief to stealth-action games. No execuse not to play, if you are a sucker for such sort of games. By the way, there are lots of great mods. Helps to forget about her...

review:
I absolutely loved SWAT 3 when growing up and I thought I'd revisit it once again 20 years later from when I first experienced it. The game still holds up as a sublime tactical shooter with excellent AI and authentic missions.

Sadly this has to be one of the most broken out-of-the-box old titles and it needs a considerable amount of work to get it running whether you opt to play outright modded or a patched vanilla version using 3rd party tools. 

It's great to see classic games like this being made available digitally but there has to be a functionality threshold whereby games work to a degree rather than the entire burden being placed on the users to get it working. 

As it stands, this is just easy extra money for an existing publisher who probably doesn't even know this game exists, from a long defunct developer. When even the GOG version is also borked, you know it has to be bad.

An old classic that deserves recognition even if it somewhat aged poorly.

review:
This is an amazing game that despite the issues and the method needed to get it running on modern hardware.

What I liked:
+Unique missions that all have replay value
+Randomized AI patterns so each deployment into the same mission is different
+A good amount of weapon choice in the 10-man career as well as Uniform customization
+Has some amazing mods which add more to the game like new guns, better graphics, new missions and more
+You can see your gun if you hit the ~ key and type 'handsup' with no quotes.

What I disliked:
-Multiple issues with modern hardware as the game is from almost a decade ago
-The AI officers will sometimes crowd in front of a door which is bad
-The 5 man career is very limited in weapon choice and has no uniform customization (The 10 man career can be done with 5 men and yes I know the 5 man was the base game and the 10 man was the DLC)
-The third mission can sometimes kill you off the bat when you turn the first corner as a enemy spawns on the balcony in the back or in front of the window in the front.

review:
The AI is over-rated but otherwise the BEST still that I have seen to date. They really do watch for all corners and move like a squad should if you let them. My only problem is that I cannot fully trust them in a fast acting scenario to assist me and survive. I am one who will and has replay'd a scenario over and over until all if not the majority of the squad is still walking. The content style, game-play, and all sound up to the voice acting is totally immersive. It's a shame that the AI breaks that immersion when they mess up. I still cherish this title as if it were gold because, I do get those satisfying moments of success over chaos quite often. Take what I have to say about the AI with a grain assault but I know you wont because, it's the truth.

AI Mishaps:
*stack up in odd bunches 
*disregard your order to advance for a hostage in an insecure area 
*Forget that there is a suspect in the room that they are clearing and fail immediatly upon entering. The hint would have been in the fallen officer that he would have tripped over if it weren't for it being a game.
*disregard another order to breach and clear to see what is going on in your breach and clear move
*When you say breach, bang, and clear it does not mean ignore everything you've learned in basic training. They'll stand in the middle of the doorway, open it, stand directly in the middle where they were, hesitate to throw the flash or deploy move, and then clear. There are better ways to handle breach, bang, and clears.

All of these actions has resulted in unintended downed officers and hostages.

review: This is the best CQB simulator available on Steam. Most would prefer SWAT 4, but SWAT 3 has a strict adherence to realism that SWAT 4 lacks and its teammate AI is probably the best I've seen in any game at all, regardless of genre. Sierra was creating AI like this in the late 90s, meanwhile games like Ground Branch and Insurgency still do not have proper singleplayer modes. The controls will need quite a bit of tweaking, since this was developed for the simulation crowd and not for FPS types. The mixed reviews are misleading; all you have to do is drop dgVoodoo 2 in the installation folder and the game runs fine, this is absolutely not a case of Steam selling a completely broken title. There are numerous mods for this game but finding them can be a bit difficult; fortunately, this game's modding system is very clean, requiring zip files to be dropped in a dedicated "mods" folder, no overwriting any game files or somesuch nonsense that most titles have now. This is the title for those of us who don't care about driving vehicles or having long-range engagements like in Ground Branch or ArmA. Bring order to chaos.

review:
A classic tactical shooter. The golden age of these games was really late '90's to the early '00's. This is an excellent example of the genre. Where Rainbow Six placed you incharge of a black ops team who is only called out when all-kill-no-capture was the only way forward, SWAT 3 places you in the boots of a SWAT officer, meaning that you are actually encouraged to capture over killing. It produces a very addictive and highly replayable tactical shooter as the placement of enemies changes with every instance.

Be sure to check out the guides to get it to work. It's not much trouble. Either way, grab this if you want actual tactical shooting goodness.

Also, yes, the community is full of crazy people whose grip on reality is tenuous at best. If you're looking for coop partners, be sure to talk at length before hand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005828025', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1598178697}
review:
Despite SWAT4 taking the eventual crown of tactical coop game due to it's impressive ease of access and simple controls, in my opinion SWAT 3 is the truely groundbraking achievement that to this day set the bar so high, modern titles can be measured by it's standards.
This is the best of the series, hands down, due to one thing that transforms SWAT series into the masterpiece - the AI. No other game, not even Rainbow Six series has ever come CLOSE to the levels of proficiency squad AI presents under our command. With every order given they move in formations, cover flanks and entry ways, as they ascend staircases, our servicemen use proper procedures. They are so efficient, you could technically go through entire game just issuing them orders and not fire a single shot yourself while doing so.
I remember people praising Hideo Kojima's MGS2 for 'emulating' realistic movements, authentic procedures, etc. while in anything but cutscenes the AI seemed dumber then a bucket of gravel. Even the sequel to this series, SWAT 4 could not match the excelence of SWAT3 in this regard. Rainbow Six's AI needed almost excessive handholding to get missions done right IF at all.

The reason I'm seriously still going on about your team's AI is crucial, cause graphics are good for the time, that's given, sound, map design, you surely have heard people praise those. But you have no idea what a game changer it is to have a TACTICAL shooter, where you can TRUELY depend on your team! It's TEAM of professionals who ACT like Professionals and no other game managed to convey that, not even most modern ARMAs or similar titles. 
(I mean sure, there are some cases where pathfinding plays tricks on you, or some bug occurs and an operative can get stuck, but those are rare cases - testament to this game's age rather than lack of effort)

If you want to play this game, go for Last Resort Mod Pack, it'll enhance your game even further.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993464013', 'num_games_owned': 689, 'num_reviews': 404, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1694286977}
review:
Wow, I am almost in tears. I spent so many years playing this when I was a younger lad and to see and hear it again after so long is something special. There is an element of tactical enjoyment that this game offers that nothing else seems to come close to.

I don't know why so many people are reporting problems getting it to run, it must be a hardware issue or software conflict within their system. This booted right up and ran fine on the first go.

There used to be a website called 10-David or something like that way back in the day which had tons of mods for this. I think it has long since closed down but this was a highly modded game 17 year ago. So many memories...

EDIT: Of note, this is not a positive review based on memories alone, this is truly a great game for its time period and is still fun to this day.
Also of note, it no longer runs on Windows 10 without intervention due to some changes on Microsoft's side. Not to fear, there are some easy steps to take and the game works beautifully and EVEN ON A 21:9 ULTRAWIDE monitor at 3440x1440.

Step 1 - Acquire a mod called Last Resort and install it per the instruction
Step 2 - All the rest of the steps are on the Last Resort site but basically just swap out the AVI video clips with some new ones that are compiled with a different codec
Step 3 - Simply install dgVooDoo2 which is very easy and, again, explained on the Last Resort site. The game will now work as though it were a modern game and it feels so buttery smooth.

The sound effects were actually quite good for this time period. The suppressed weapons sound realistic in a time when every other game used the Hollywood sounds. The voice actors are incredibly good and really sound like a SWAT team. You will be in constant communication with the commander, informing them of what is going on and evacuating survivors, etc. 

The best part of the game is that you can choose to either take charge and get stuff done on your own or you can sit back and have your teams handle it like a manager. Such a truly great game

author: {'steamid': '76561197999996623', 'num_games_owned': 2730, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1530173180}
review:
Best tactical shooter ever made! Even better than SWAT 4 because the AI in SWAT 3 is much better. That's saying a lot because I love SWAT 4. Buy it, even if it's not on sale.

Don't be put off by the Mixed reviews....most of the negative ones are made by people that can't get it to run on Windows 10 and that refuse to spend 15 seconds to search for a solution. Just Google it...or better yet, I'll link my guide at the bottom of this review. There, now you have no excuse not to pull the trigger (pun intended).

SWAT 3 has what shitty watered-down modern shooters lack....depth, story, and real tactical planning. You have full control over your squad and as touched on before, the AI is impecable. Path finding is spot on, and your team's ability to actually pull off your commands only adds to the immersion factor.

The graphics are actually quite good, especially for a game released originally in 1999. The "Last Resort" mod makes it look even better. I actually favor the graphics in SWAT 3 over the new modern wax figure look. The locations are amazingly detailed and well thought out (stellar level design). The audio is a standout too....even has epic music, which you wouldn't expect in a squad based shooter.

I just can't say enough good things about SWAT 3. It's got a reputation for being the best tactical shooter still to this day for a reason. If you like run & gun, run amok, multiplayer cluster fucks....then stay away. Battle Royale this is not! But if you like strategic planning, lethal force as a last resort, and commanding a squad (5 or 10 man teams) then SWAT 3 is for you!

review:
[h1]Forget Tom Clancy[/h1]

The sheer tactical depth of this game, guys. Seriously.
I don't care if it's 2018 - if you are fans of hardcore tactical challenge, buy this game and get the Last Resort mod. You'll have to tweak a little bit for compatibility with Windows versions older than Vista, but it's worth it.
No game was able to give you this level of tactical depth so far, not even Swat 4, which is ruined by a worse AI than its predecessor.
I'm talking AI keeping seriously smart corners, moving with painstaking precision, being reactive like a highly trained officer. Suspects will camp in smart areas, will retreat, regroup and try to get around you. Hostages will panic, and either flee or get on the ground. But it goes deeper: you need to study the planimetry and intel on tango gear, decide entry points for one or two teams, pick smart loadouts with different types of ammo and other gadgets; you the need to report people you down or restrain for trailers to intervene while you sweep further areas.
I mean, come on.
The challenges you face are low in polygons but high in core realism.
Audio is also a plus: radio chatter is functional, atmospheric and mostly not too invasive.
It's all very rough around the edges, but if you consider that this game was first sold in 1999 you just can't wrap your head around it.

Note on time played: I played this game since I was 10, and I recently bought it again. Also, Steam won't compute the time I'm spending playing in Last Resort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015504868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1493181683}
review:
This game hasn't aged well in its mechanical execution. It provides tactical depth (which is a good base to continue working from) however it is not presented in a way that offers intuitive, clean and fluid gameplay experiences and mechanics compared to the sequel SWAT4. 

Recognise any nostalgic bias you may have when determining objective critical analysis of the game itself to modern standards. Asking for a game to be presented in a better way does not mean it will lose the tacitcal depth. No-one is asking for the game to be "dumbed down" or "become a fast paced arcade shooter". 

A few examples of how this game hasn't aged well include:
[list]
[*]I tell my team to stack up on a door to a room from within a hallway. I want to reposition myself on the side opposite side of the door from the team so I can quickly enter and assess the situation once we breach, however my team doesn't move out of the way so it takes longer than it needs to. In SWAT4 the A.I recognises I'm trying to get somewhere and will move to make room and then move back into position.
[*]The number keys are used to control your team and most interactions. This requires you to take your hands off either movement keys or the mouse to do almost anything. This doesn't make for dynamic and fluid gameplay. SWAT4 offers contextual quick keys and allows you to control your team without stopping you from either moving and/or aiming/shooting at the same time.
[*]When you lockpick a door it flings open immediately after. SWAT4 keeps the door closed after its picked open.
[*]When you lean left or right, you need to press a third seperate button to return your character to the default stance. In many other games either letting go of the button or pressing the same button again would return you to a normal stance.[/list]
I purchased this game and gave it a positive review to show my support for the series in a hope that SWAT4 gets released on Steam and that maybe one day Activision releases a SWAT5 sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981621715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1492598487}
review:
Wow.. I've been waiting so many years to have this game on Steam that I'm simply lost for words. Well done to Sierra for finally laying that grudge to rest.

Far superior to its sequel, the challenging AI is matched only in its impressiveness by your own fellow AI SWAT team whom you can nimbly control with numpad commands. The randomised nature of the hostage and enemy placement in missions (as well as whether they are armed/their predisposition to listen to your commands/emotional state) leads to every replay presenting a new challenge and with the ability to equip your element with a variety of different lethal/non-lethal guns and tools before the mission you will find yourself taking many different approaches.

The graphics were dated even at release, however, much in the same way that the original Deus Ex can still be enjoyed by looking past its visuals this game is also worthy of that regard. It still holds up today and is especially entertaining in multiplayer.

One point worthy of note is that there are issues with the game working on Windows 8/10 due to the way the game is rendered - you can circumvent this to an extent by using dgVoodoo2 which gives you a large increase in performance (enough for me to enjoy playing the game).

FFO: Rainbow 6, Hidden & Dangerous, Operation Flashpoint, Door Kickers, Police Quest
